prompt: Who should do the legwork of gathering the marketplace data for the Product Owner? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The Scrum Team and the Key Stakeholders.
It does not matter who does the legwork.

prompt: True or False: Scrum does only require monitoring of progress toward goals or sprint goals.
What KVMs might be considered when establishing a Scrum Team's Ability to Innovate? Select the best three answers.
explanation: Evidence-Based Management uses KVAs (Current Value, Time-to-Market, Ability to Innovate, Unrealized Value) and KVMs under each. Typical Ability to Innovate measures include Innovation Rate, Defect trends, Technical Debt ratio, Build/Deployment frequency, etc. Installed Version Index aligns more with Time-to-Market; Usage Index/Customer Satisfaction align with Current Value.

prompt: Who identifies the Key Stakeholders for the Product? Choose the best answer.
explanation: The Scrum Team collaborates to identify and engage stakeholders. The PO leads stakeholder collaboration because they’re accountable for maximizing product value.

prompt: What preconditions must be fulfilled in order to allow Sprint Planning to begin. Choose the best answer.

options.text: Enough ‘ready’ Product Backlog Items to fill the Sprint.
A clear and non-negotiable Sprint Goal.

prompt: Which is the most important stakeholder Product Owners must satisfy? Choose the best answer.
True or False: The Product Owner should be expertly aware of the marketplace for the product.
Which KVAs should a Product Owner consider to measure and track the creation and delivery of value to the marketplace? Select the best three answers.
Which of the following does NOT help a Scrum Team to increase its release frequency? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Synchronizing the release schedules across all teams in the development organization

explanation: Synchronizing release schedules across all teams tends to add coordination overhead and batching, which reduces release frequency. Automation, refinement, dependency reduction normally increase release cadence.

prompt: True or False: A Scrum Team can have an exclusive first Sprint to prepare a Product Backlog, which is the sole outcome for that Sprint.
When should the Product Owner update the project plan? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Scrum forbids having a project plan
After the Daily Scrum to ensure an accurate daily overview of project progress
Before Sprint Planning to know how much work will have to be done in the Sprint
The Product Backlog is the plan in Scrum. It is updated as new information and insights emerge

prompt: If a Sprint needs to be reprioritized in a hurry for any reason, who should reprioritize? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The whole Scrum Team including Product Owner and Developers

explanation: Developers own the Sprint Backlog (the plan). Scope can be re-negotiated with the PO during the Sprint to protect the Sprint Goal. Changes happen via PO+Developers collaboration, not unilaterally.

prompt: True or False: Being agile is about responding to change. That is why during a Sprint, if the Product Owner thinks of a new feature, he/she can add it to the Sprint Backlog.
Which metrics will help a Product Owner establish that value is being delivered? Choose the best two answers.
explanation: Time-to-Market and Customer Satisfaction are outcome-oriented signals of value. Velocity, productivity, scope implemented are activity/output metrics.

prompt: True or False: A first Sprint can start before the Product Owner has a complete and exhaustive Product Backlog in place.
True or False: Each increment contains only Done functionality that must be released immediately.
What is the primary benefit of an agile approach as compared to a waterfall approach? Choose the best answer.

options.text: To deliver on-time, on-budget, and on scope.

explanation: To maximize value via frequent, usable increments enabling inspection and adaptation. Predictability and schedule adherence are secondary outcomes, not the primary benefit.

prompt: Who can change the priority of items in the Product Backlog at any time? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The Product Owner and the Developers in a collaborative effort

explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for ordering the Product Backlog. Others may influence; the PO decides.

prompt: What two things best help the Product Owner manage the value of a product? Choose the best two answers.

options.text: Setting value on individual Product Backlog items using Value Poker.
Devising a formula for a neutral calculation of value.
Validating assumptions of value through frequent releases.
The order of the Product Backlog.

prompt: True or False: Implementing a survey on a website that collects data about potential users of your product is a valid release and does provide value.
explanation: A release can be an experiment that yields validated learning—a legitimate form of value in empiricism.

prompt: True or False: The Product Owner must be present during at least the first half of Sprint Planning.
explanation: The PO’s participation is essential, but there’s no “half-sprint-planning” rule. The entire Scrum Team collaborates to create the Sprint Goal and plan.

prompt: A Scrum Team is introducing “Quality Assurance and Release Readiness Meetings”. Which KVM is affected? Choose the best answer.
explanation: Such gates typically delay release flow, negatively impacting Time-to-Market (e.g., Release Stabilization).

prompt: True or False: During the Sprint Review it is up to the stakeholders to reorder the Product Backlog.
explanation: Stakeholders provide feedback; ordering is the Product Owner’s accountability.

prompt: A representative of the customer has asked the Developers to add a very important item to an ongoing Sprint. What should the Developers do? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Refer the representative to the Scrum Master to discuss it.
Refuse it, because they are in the middle of the Sprint.
Accept it only if they are willing to ask for it formally.
Bring this to the attention of the whole Scrum Team to discuss it.

explanation: Bring it to the whole Scrum Team (PO + Developers) to inspect and potentially re-negotiate scope without endangering the Sprint Goal.

prompt: Which statement is true about multiple Scrum Teams working on the same product? Choose the best answer.

options.text: They should have one Product Backlog and multiple Product Owners.
They should have multiple Product Backlogs and multiple Product Owners.
They should have multiple Product Backlogs and one Product Owner.
They should have one Product Backlog and one Product Owner.

explanation: Use one Product Backlog and one Product Owner to maintain single-source transparency and coherent ordering across teams.

prompt: You are Product Owner with several Scrum Teams on the same product. Most teams have a velocity between 30–35 story points per Sprint. One team consistently delivers only 12–15 story points per Sprint. Is this a cause for concern? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Yes, this is a cause for concern. The slow team has not calibrated their story points with the other teams.
No, this is not a cause for concern. The slower team will probably increase their velocity over time.
Yes, this is a cause for concern. You should push the slower team harder to catch up with the other teams.
Yes, this is a cause for concern. The slow team is performing worse than the rest and should be punished.
Yes, this is a cause for concern. The Scrum Master of the slow team is not making it as productive as the other teams.
No, this is not a cause for concern. Velocity is not a measurement of value delivered.

explanation: Velocity is not a value metric. Different teams use story points differently; focus on outcomes and impediments, not cross-team velocity comparisons.

prompt: In order to maximize the value of a product, a Product Owner needs awareness of the following: Choose all that apply.

options.text: Tools and techniques used by the Developers

prompt: What are two characteristics of the Product Owner? Choose the best two answers.

options.text: Lead Scrum evangelist in the organization

prompt: Who should do the legwork of gathering the marketplace data for the Product Owner? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The Scrum Team and the Key Stakeholders
It does not matter who does the legwork

prompt: Scrum Teams have to balance many varying objectives. Which of the following is the most important objective? Choose the best answer.
The Product Owner wants to create estimations and asks the Scrum Master for guidance. How should the Scrum Master respond? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Product Owners should use manhours for estimation
Product Owners should use Story Points for estimation
There is no estimation in Scrum
Estimations are created by the Developers. The Product Owner may be consulted for clarification

prompt: When does Product Backlog Refinement take place? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The Scrum Team defines how and when refinement is done

prompt: A development organization has many Scrum Teams working on different products. How can management understand the status of each team? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Each team should create a detailed forecast of their work, then track plan versus actual performance
Standardize Story Point estimates across all teams so managers can compare velocity
Each team should fill out a status report to provide information that can be shared with the managers
The teams should work together to develop a common way of sharing their Sprint Goals and what they achieve in each Sprint against these Goals

prompt: What KVMs might be considered when establishing a Scrum Team’s Ability to Innovate? Select the best three answers.
Product Backlog Refinement… Select the best two answers.

options.text: answers the question: how will the work needed to deliver the increment be achieved
usually happens 2–4 times in dependency of the Sprint length
is the act of adding detail, estimates, and order to Product Backlog Items

prompt: True or False: Scrum does only require monitoring of progress toward goals or sprint goals.
explanation: True in spirit: Scrum emphasizes transparency/inspection toward the Product Goal and Sprint Goal. Other metrics are optional complements; the core is frequent inspection/adaptation against goals.

prompt: A Product Owner…

options.text: …will need to understand the technical aspects of development, to contribute effectively.
…will always receive lower-quality products than their non-Agile counterparts.
…must have a thorough understanding of Agile techniques, for Agile to work.
…will typically get business value delivered early and often.

prompt: Who has the final say on the order of the Product Backlog? Choose the best answer.
When the Developers on a Scrum Team are having trouble delivering a working increment because they don't understand a functional requirement, what should they do? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Defer the work to a more appropriate Sprint.
Add a specialist to the Scrum Team.
Partially complete the functionality and discuss the remaining work at the Sprint Review.
Collaborate with the Product Owner to determine what is possible and acceptable.

prompt: Which event in Scrum helps a Scrum Team to improve on a continuing basis? Choose the best answer.
Who has the authority to cancel the Sprint? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Product Owner with permission of the Scrum Master

explanation: Only the Product Owner can cancel a Sprint, typically when the Sprint Goal becomes obsolete. Done work is reviewed; undone work returns to the Product Backlog.

prompt: A product is… (Choose all that apply.)

options.text: …a service, a physical product, or something abstract.
…defined by clear boundaries, known stakeholders and well-defined users or customers.

explanation: A product can be a service, a physical good, or something abstract, with clear boundaries, known stakeholders, and well-defined users/customers; it is a vehicle to deliver value.

prompt: Who is accountable for creating the most valuable product possible? Choose the best answer.
What preconditions must be fulfilled in order to allow Sprint Planning to begin? Choose the best answer.

options.text: A clear and non-negotiable Sprint Goal.
Enough “ready” Product Backlog Items to fill the Sprint.

prompt: True or False: The Product Owner can delegate his/her accountabilities to others.
explanation: The PO may delegate work, but accountability remains with the PO.

prompt: True or False: The Scrum Master should not allow the Product Owner to attend the Sprint Planning if the Product Owner is not ready with a Sprint Goal.
How does the Product Owner communicate his/her marketplace knowledge to the Scrum Team? Choose the best three answers.
explanation: Reiterating: Refinement, Sprint Reviews, and ongoing collaboration are the primary channels; not Daily Scrum/Retrospective.

prompt: True or False: Every Increment must be released.
explanation: Every Increment must be usable and meet the Definition of Done; releasing is a PO decision based on value/context.

prompt: Which of the following are NOT true about the Product Owner? Choose the best two answers.

options.text: The Product Owner is accountable for ordering the Product Backlog.
The Product Owner role can be played by a committee or a team of people.
The Product Owner can be influenced by those wanting to change the Product Backlog.
The Product Owner is one person.
Multiple persons can share the Product Owner role on a Scrum Team.

explanation: The Product Owner is one person, not a committee, and the role is not shared. Others may help, but accountability remains with a single PO.

prompt: The Scrum Master observes the Product Owner struggling with ordering the Product Backlog. What would you consider an appropriate action for the Scrum Master to take? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Present the Product Owner an ordered Product Backlog to use.
Suggest to the Product Owner to extend the Sprint, so he/she can have more time ordering the Product Backlog.
Encourage the Product Owner to work with the Developers to see which items technically are fastest to implement.
Suggest that the Developers do the ordering.
Offer the Product Owner help in ordering the Product Backlog from an understanding the goal is to maximize value.

prompt: True or False: A Product Owner has the authority to replace an item in the Sprint Backlog.
explanation: The Developers own the Sprint Backlog. PO and Developers may re-negotiate scope to protect the Sprint Goal, but the PO cannot unilaterally swap items.

prompt: What three things might a Scrum Product Owner focus on to ensure the product delivers value? Choose the best three answers.

options.text: How readily the product can be absorbed and used by the customers.
How much of the functionality of the product is being utilized.

prompt: An organization has several Scrum Teams working on one product. How can be determined which team is performing the best? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Begin to normalize the estimates across the Scrum Teams. Based on that create a balanced scorecard.
A good way is to examine several different measures like velocity, defects, and technical debt. This will provide a detailed picture of which team is performing the best.
The team with the highest velocity is the best-performing team.
Comparing team performance leads to unhealthy behaviors. Rather focus on identifying and removing impediments that keep the teams from performing better.

prompt: Who is required to attend the Daily Scrums? Choose the best answer.
explanation: The Daily Scrum is by and for the Developers. Others may observe only if they don’t disrupt.

prompt: What is an important accountability of a Scrum Master? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Dictate Sprint Goals and ensure they are met every Sprint.
Prioritize the work and make sure that high value work gets done.
Ensure that the Scrum Team has what it needs to be successful and remove impediments that hinder them in their progress.

prompt: Which of the following statements show a mindset that will make an implementation of the Scrum Framework easier? Choose the best answer.

options.text: "Stakeholder satisfaction is the best measure of value delivered."
"Projects are successful when they finish on time, on budget and on scope."
"Sticking to the plan is the hallmark of a good project manager."
"Surprises are not good. They show that someone has not done their homework."
"Projects fail because there was not enough focus on planning."
"Unexpected things will come our way. If we use them to learn, it is acceptable."

prompt: How frequently should the Product Owner communicate and re-iterate the Product Goal to the Scrum Team and stakeholders? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Once at the first Sprint Planning.

prompt: Who has the authority to cancel a Sprint? Choose the best answer.
What should the Developers do if the Product Owner is repeatedly too busy to be available? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Send the customer a written warning that the end product will be completed on time, but may not meet their needs.
Continue the work, record the assumptions and ask the customer later for input.
Allow the Business Analyst to take on the role of Proxy Customer Representative.
Draw the problem to the attention of the Scrum Master.

prompt: Which of the following statements about Technical Debt (deferred work for the product by technical shortcuts to trade quality for speed) is correct? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Technical Debt is a sign of poor development practices.
Technical Debt can be handled in a dedicated Maintenance Sprint.
Technical Debt is a mere technical concern and thus only relevant for developers.
Technical Debt is a real threat to the long-term viability of a product.

prompt: True or False: Metrics can help to validate business hypotheses and the impact of product releases.
explanation: Empiricism requires clear hypotheses + measures (leading/lagging indicators). Use sound experiment design (A/B tests, control groups) to reduce bias.

prompt: Who identifies the Key Stakeholders for the Product? Choose the best answer.
explanation: The Scrum Team collaborates to identify and engage stakeholders. The PO leads stakeholder collaboration because they’re accountable for maximizing product value.

prompt: True or False: There is no one in a Scrum Team called “project manager”.
True or False: A Product Owner can measure whether value is being delivered by an increase in the team's velocity.
True or False: Hardening Sprints are needed every few Sprints to resolve dependencies and reduce technical debt.
A product's success is measured by: Choose the best three answers.

options.text: The impact on my performance rating.
The impact on the CEO's mood.
The delivery of upfront defined scope compared to upfront planned time.

prompt: Which of the following measures might help a Product Owner to determine whether the product under development is delivering value to customers? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The on-time, on-schedule, on-budget performance of the Scrum Team.
The costs of each product release.
The number of 'must-do' Product Backlog items delivered each release.
How often do the customers use the product.

prompt: Product Backlog Items are refined by… Choose the best answer.

options.text: The Business Analyst and the Product Owner.

prompt: True or False: The Developers on a Scrum Team are accountable for releasing the most valuable product possible.

In order to make investment decisions, the Product Owner is likely to look at the Total Cost of Ownership of the product being developed. What costs will a Product Owner take into account to make this decision? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The money that has been spent on development of the product, often a fixed costs per Sprint multiplied by the Sprints required.
The accumulated costs over the earned value of the product.
All investments required to conceive, develop, operate and maintain the product.

prompt: How can the Product Owner bring the Product Goal to life? Select the best three answers.

options.text: Making the Scrum Master articulate the Product Goal to the Scrum Team and the Key Stakeholders.
Asking for an approval of the Upper Management.
Via the Product Backlog and iterating towards the Product Goal every Sprint.
Utilizing the underlying empirical product planning features of Scrum.
Communicating the Product Goal to the Scrum Team and the Stakeholders early and often.

prompt: The duration (length) of the Sprint is decided by… Choose the best answer.
Release Stabilization as a Key Value Measure is part of which Key Value Area?
Team A has an average velocity of 30. Team B has an average velocity 42. Which team is delivering more value? Choose the best answer.

options.text: We do not know. Velocity is not a measure of value.

explanation: No. Velocity is an output measure (throughput), not an outcome measure. Value is validated by releasing usable increments and observing customer/business impact (e.g., adoption, retention, revenue, risk reduction)

prompt: How does the Scrum Master help the Product Owner? Choose the best two answers.

options.text: Assisting in ordering the Product Backlog.
Leading and coaching the organization in its Scrum adoption.
Helping establish empirical product planning for a complex environment.
Helping find techniques for effective Product Goal definition and Product Backlog management.

prompt: My job as a Product Owner focuses on the following: Choose the best two answers.

options.text: Being with Scrum Team all the time, just in case they need my to clarify a requirement.
Clearly communicating project or release status and strategies to customers and stakeholders.
Working with customers and stakeholders to identify the most valuable, most important product requirements.

prompt: A Product Owner is attaching incentives to value metrics to improve team morale and productivity. Is this acceptable? Choose the best answer.

options.text: Yes, this will increase morale and productivity.
No, incentives can lead to unhealthy behavior in the Scrum Team.

explanation: Tying incentives to “value” often drives gaming, creates local optima, and can reduce intrinsic motivation. Use metrics to learn and improve, not to reward/punish.

prompt:
In an organization managers have used periodic status report meetings and one-on-one meetings to understand how a team was doing. How can Scrum provide the same insights without creating any additional meetings? Choose the best two answers.
Please select all the answers that apply

options.text: Managers should attend Sprint Retrospectives of the Team to gain insights on how the team is doing.
The Scrum Master is the single source of information with regard to team performance.
It is a valid assumption that the Scrum Master will ensure the Scrum Team is working well.
Keep the Product Backlog transparent and clear to all.
Scrum Teams may add the most impactful improvements coming from the Sprint Retrospective to the Sprint Backlog.

explanation: Scrum relies on artifact and work transparency rather than extra status meetings. A clear Product Backlog lets anyone see priorities and intent, and making improvements from the Retrospective visible in the Sprint Backlog provides insight into how the team is improving—without adding new ceremonies. The Scrum Master is not a "single source" of status, and managers should not attend the Sprint Retrospective.

prompt: As a Product Owner you discover that a number of features you thought were important are never or rarely used. What actions can you take to generate further insight into this? Select the best three answers.

options.text: You disable all the features that are never or rarely used.
You start to run small experiments to help you understand what the customer finds valuable.
You spend more time talking to the product's users to find out more about the impact they seek in the product.
You examine if the rarely used features really solve the intended problem.

explanation: Use empiricism: validate value via experiments, qualitative user discovery, and problem–solution fit checks. Turning features off blindly risks harming existing value.

prompt: A Product Owner requests the Developers to assist him/her with understanding non-functional requirements in the Product Backlog. Which of the following is true. Select the best two answers.

options.text: The Developers should refer the Product Owner to the Scrum Team Manager.
The Scrum Master should step in and coach the Product Owner.
This is acceptable. However, the Product Owner is still accountable for the Product Backlog.
Developers can volunteer to assist the Product Owner.

explanation: Collaboration is expected. The Product Owner remains accountable for the Product Backlog, but Developers’ technical input (including NFRs) improves clarity and feasibility.

prompt: The market and environment in which a product is used changes and emerges. What is the effect on the Product Backlog? Choose the best answer.

options.text: The requirements specification document, describing the Product Backlog items, must be updated.
The Product Backlog is archived and a new Product Backlog is created to take its place.
There is no effect, because the Product Backlog must stay the same until the end of the project.
The Product Backlog evolves to reflect what the product needs to be most valuable.

explanation: The Product Backlog is emergent and changes as the product and its environment change so the team can maximize value.

prompt: True or False: Lower positioned Product Backlog Items are usually larger in size and less clear than those at the top of the Product Backlog.
explanation: Backlogs are typically refined top-down: higher-ordered items are smaller and clearer; lower-ordered items are larger and less detailed.

prompt: True or False: The Product Owner can change the priority of the items in the Product Backlog at any time.
explanation: The Product Owner is accountable for ordering the Product Backlog and may change order whenever needed to optimize value.

prompt: The Developers on a Scrum Team ask their Product Owner to re-order the Product Backlog. The team is waiting for an external supplier to deliver a specific component. Without that component there won't be enough work in the next Sprint to occupy the full team. The Product Owner asks the Scrum Master for help. What would be a good advice to give the Product Owner. Choose the best answer.

options.text: Tell the Product Owner that the Product Backlog should be ordered to maximize utilization of the Developers.
Tell the Product Owner to re-order the Product Backlog so the work involving the external component can be planned in a separate Sprint.
Remind the Product Owner that their primary concern is the flow of value reflected in the ordering of the Product Backlog.

explanation: Ordering should reflect maximizing value and learning, not maximizing utilization or batching work around external constraints. (Options reconstructed from the canonical version of this question used earlier.)

prompt: The Product Owner decides how many Product Backlog Items should be selected for the next Sprint. Choose the best answer.

options.text: False, the Scrum Master does that.
Correct, based on the agreement with the stakeholders.

explanation: Selection is made by the Developers based on capacity and the Sprint Goal. The Product Owner orders the Product Backlog; they do not dictate the number of items.
